articles.headline: 3 Winners, but No Anchor for Republicans
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s victory in Michigan means that three very different states have embraced three candidates.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s victory in Michigan means that three very different states have embraced three candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can anyone bring the Republicans together again?

articles.headline: Romney in Crucial Victory Over McCain in Michigan
articles.snippet: Pledging to renew the automobile industry, Mitt Romney defeated his principal rival, Senator John McCain.
articles.abstract: Pledging to renew the automobile industry, Mitt Romney defeated his principal rival, Senator John McCain.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor who ran as a son of Michigan though he left the state nearly 40 years ago, won a commanding victory Tuesday in the Republican primary here with a message aimed at voters deeply anxious about the state’s ailing economy.

articles.headline: An Effort to Stem Losses at Citigroup Produces a Renewed Focus on Risk
articles.snippet: Doling out credit, but with an eye on the balance sheet.
articles.abstract: Doling out credit, but with an eye on the balance sheet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ben Bernanke, meet Gary Crittenden. While you’re easing credit, he is tightening it.

articles.headline: Citigroup Loss Raises Anxiety Over Economy
articles.snippet: Reporting a fourth-quarter loss of $9.83 billion, Citigroup also issued a forecast that the economy had not yet bottomed out.
articles.abstract: Reporting a fourth-quarter loss of $9.83 billion, Citigroup also issued a forecast that the economy had not yet bottomed out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup, the nation’s largest bank, reported a staggering fourth-quarter loss of $9.83 billion on Tuesday and issued a sobering forecast that the housing market and the broader economy still had not bottomed out.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Interest Fades in the Once-Mighty V-8
articles.snippet: Long a symbol of power for American car companies, the V-8 engine is sputtering as Detroit’s Big Three promote smaller engines and alternative-fuel vehicles.
articles.abstract: Long a symbol of power for American car companies, the V-8 engine is sputtering as Detroit’s Big Three promote smaller engines and alternative-fuel vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The V-8 engine, long a symbol of power for American car companies, is sputtering.

articles.headline: Buddy, Can You Spare a Billion?
articles.snippet: First, hard-pressed Wall Street banks turned to rich foreign governments for help. Now, they are seeking aid from the likes of New Jersey and big mutual funds.
articles.abstract: First, hard-pressed Wall Street banks turned to rich foreign governments for help. Now, they are seeking aid from the likes of New Jersey and big mutual funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: First hard-pressed Wall Street banks turned to rich foreign governments for help. Now, they are seeking aid from the likes of New Jersey and big mutual funds to bolster their weakened finances.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Says Food From Cloned Animals Is Safe
articles.snippet: Despite the F.D.A. endorsement, the Agriculture Department has asked farmers to continue withholding clones from the food supply.
articles.abstract: Despite the F.D.A. endorsement, the Agriculture Department has asked farmers to continue withholding clones from the food supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of debate, the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday declared that food from cloned animals and their progeny is safe to eat, clearing the way for milk and meat derived from genetic copies of prized dairy cows, steers and hogs to be sold at the grocery store.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: Supreme Court Limits Lawsuits by Shareholders
articles.snippet: In its most important securities fraud ruling in years, the Supreme Court placed a huge obstacle before shareholders looking to sue someone after a stock purchase turns sour.
articles.abstract: In its most important securities fraud ruling in years, the Supreme Court placed a huge obstacle before shareholders looking to sue someone after a stock purchase turns sour.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Ruling in its most important securities fraud case in years, the Supreme Court on Tuesday placed a towering obstacle in the path of shareholders looking for someone to sue when a stock purchase turns sour.

articles.headline: A Revival of 1992’s Glum Mood
articles.snippet: The details of the economic slump have changed since the ’92 presidential race, but the main story line remains much the same.
articles.abstract: The details of the economic slump have changed since the ’92 presidential race, but the main story line remains much the same.
